column1: When enabled the module will produce logs through Magento logging system.

column1: Enable logging of requests that produce errors
column2: Enable logging of requests that produce errors

column1: This is an alternative to the debug mode for production environments. If enabled, even when the debug mode is disabled, the body of search requests that produce an error will be logged. If disabled, only the error message/exception message will be logged (legacy behavior). A log rotation system on the var/log/system.log file is advised if enabled.
column2: This is an alternative to the debug mode for production environments. If enabled, even when the debug mode is disabled, the body of search requests that produce an error will be logged. If disabled, only the error message/exception message will be logged (legacy behavior). A log rotation system on the var/log/system.log file is advised if enabled.

column2: The value should be different to zero.

column1: Number of words to match at the beginning of the string
column2: Number of words to match at the beginning of the string

column1: [Experimental] Use reference analyzer in exact matching filter query
column2: [Experimental] Use reference analyzer in exact matching filter query

column1: Experimental: Instead of the 'sku' field, use the 'reference' collector field which contains all searchable fields using the 'reference' analyzer when building the exact/most exact matching filter query. Useful for sku/reference matching.
column2: Experimental: Instead of the 'sku' field, use the 'reference' collector field which contains all searchable fields using the 'reference' analyzer when building the exact/most exact matching filter query. Useful for sku/reference matching.

column1: [Experimental] Use all tokens from term vectors
column2: [Experimental] Use all tokens from term vectors

column1: Experimental: Take into account all tokens from the term vectors response, instead of one token per position. Useful for sku/reference matching.
column2: Experimental: Take into account all tokens from the term vectors response, instead of one token per position. Useful for sku/reference matching.

column1: [Experimental] Use reference analyzer in term vectors
column2: [Experimental] Use reference analyzer in term vectors

column1: Experimental: Include the 'reference' collector field which contains all searchable fields using the 'reference' analyzer when performing the term vectors request. Useful for sku/reference matching.
column2: Experimental: Include the 'reference' collector field which contains all searchable fields using the 'reference' analyzer when performing the term vectors request. Useful for sku/reference matching.

column1: [Experimental] Use edge ngram analyzer in term vectors
column2: [Experimental] Use edge ngram analyzer in term vectors

column1: Experimental: Include the 'edge_ngram' collector field which contains all searchable fields using an analyzer containing an edge ngram component (like 'standard_edge_ngram') when performing the term vectors request. Useful for triggering exact matching on partial search terms that are only present in fields using an edge ngram component.
column2: Experimental: Include the 'edge_ngram' collector field which contains all searchable fields using an analyzer containing an edge ngram component (like 'standard_edge_ngram') when performing the term vectors request. Useful for triggering exact matching on partial search terms that are only present in fields using an edge ngram component.

column1: [Experimental] Use default analyzer in exact matching filter query
column2: [Experimental] Use default analyzer in exact matching filter query

column1: Experimental: Use the default analyzer of each field instead of the 'standard' analyzer for exact matching. Eg : for sku, it will try to match on 'sku.reference' field. If a field is using 'standard_edge_ngram' analyzer, it will try to match on 'field.standard_edge_ngram'. Useful for partial matching, or matching on beginning of words.
column2: Experimental: Use the default analyzer of each field instead of the 'standard' analyzer for exact matching. Eg : for sku, it will try to match on 'sku.reference' field. If a field is using 'standard_edge_ngram' analyzer, it will try to match on 'field.standard_edge_ngram'. Useful for partial matching, or matching on beginning of words.

column1: An integer greater than 0. Documents with a score lower than min_score are not included in the search results.
column2: An integer greater than 0. Documents with a score lower than min_score are not included in the search results.

column1: [Experimental] Enable single term custom boost values
column2: [Experimental] Enable single term custom boost values

column1: Experimental: By default, in an exact match query, when a single term is searched, the phrase match boost value (defaults to 10) is used to both a) boost matches in the 'whitespace' version of searchable attributes/fields, in addition of their own search weight and b) apply a double boost (so defaults to 20) on matches in the 'sortable' version of searchable+sortable attributes/fields, in addition of their own search weight. This puts a huge emphasis on accurate "exactly as the user typed it" matches compared to possible singular/plural/conjugated verbs variations. Enable this setting to allow you to choose alternative boost values to use in each case.
column2: Experimental: By default, in an exact match query, when a single term is searched, the phrase match boost value (defaults to 10) is used to both a) boost matches in the 'whitespace' version of searchable attributes/fields, in addition of their own search weight and b) apply a double boost (so defaults to 20) on matches in the 'sortable' version of searchable+sortable attributes/fields, in addition of their own search weight. This puts a huge emphasis on accurate "exactly as the user typed it" matches compared to possible singular/plural/conjugated verbs variations. Enable this setting to allow you to choose alternative boost values to use in each case.

column1: [Experimental] Single term phrase match boost value
column2: [Experimental] Single term phrase match boost value

column1: Experimental: When a single term is searched, a 'whitespace' (instead of 'shingle') part of the exact match query combines the attribute/field search weight with the phrase match boost value (defaults to 10). So for instance, the 'whitespace' version of a product 'name' attribute with a search weight of 5 would be boosted by 50. You can lower that boost value to reduce the scoring gaps between 'standard' exact matches and 'whitespace' exact matches.
column2: Experimental: When a single term is searched, a 'whitespace' (instead of 'shingle') part of the exact match query combines the attribute/field search weight with the phrase match boost value (defaults to 10). So for instance, the 'whitespace' version of a product 'name' attribute with a search weight of 5 would be boosted by 50. You can lower that boost value to reduce the scoring gaps between 'standard' exact matches and 'whitespace' exact matches.

column1: [Experimental] Single term sortable matches boost value
column2: [Experimental] Single term sortable matches boost value

column1: Experimental: The 'sortable' part of the exact match query combines the attribute/field search weight with twice the phrase match boost value (so defaults to 20). So for instance, the 'sortable' version of a product 'name' attribute with a search weight of 5 would be boosted by 100. You can lower that boost value to reduce the scoring gaps between 'standard' exact matches and 'sortable' exact matches.
column2: Experimental: The 'sortable' part of the exact match query combines the attribute/field search weight with twice the phrase match boost value (so defaults to 20). So for instance, the 'sortable' version of a product 'name' attribute with a search weight of 5 would be boosted by 100. You can lower that boost value to reduce the scoring gaps between 'standard' exact matches and 'sortable' exact matches.

column1: When set to 'yes', the fuzzy queries will use the default value for the Minimum Should Match, defined in Relevance Configuration > Fulltext Base Settings > Minimum Should Match.
column2: When set to 'yes', the fuzzy queries will use the default value for the Minimum Should Match, defined in Relevance Configuration > Fulltext Base Settings > Minimum Should Match.

column1: Indices and fields configuration, redundant computations (queries spellchecking, synonyms).
column2: Indices and fields configuration, redundant computations (queries spellchecking, synonyms).

column1: Remove leading zeroes of numeric parts
column2: Remove leading zeroes of numeric parts

column1: If enabled, when indexing a reference like "VT0009", it will be as if "VT9" was indexed instead (leading to independant elements "VT", "9" and "VT9" in the search index). This will allow someone searching for "vt9" or "vt 9" to find the product with the exact "VT0009" sku.
column2: If enabled, when indexing a reference like "VT0009", it will be as if "VT9" was indexed instead (leading to independant elements "VT", "9" and "VT9" in the search index). This will allow someone searching for "vt9" or "vt 9" to find the product with the exact "VT0009" sku.

column1: Remove trailing zeroes of numeric parts
column2: Remove trailing zeroes of numeric parts

column1: If enabled, when indexing a reference like "DC3000", it will be as if "DC3" was indexed instead (leading to independant elements "DC", "3" and "DC3" in the search index). This will allow someone searching for "dc3" or "dc 3" to find the product with the exact "DC3000" sku.
column2: If enabled, when indexing a reference like "DC3000", it will be as if "DC3" was indexed instead (leading to independant elements "DC", "3" and "DC3" in the search index). This will allow someone searching for "dc3" or "dc 3" to find the product with the exact "DC3000" sku.

column1: Reduce series of contiguous zeroes in numeric parts
column2: Reduce series of contiguous zeroes in numeric parts

column1: If enabled, when indexing a reference like "PL20004", it will be as if "PL204" was indexed instead (leading to independant elements "PL", "204" and "PL204" in the search index). This will allow someone searching for "pl204", "pl 204", "pl2004" or "pl 2004" to find the product with the exact "PL2004" sku.
column2: If enabled, when indexing a reference like "PL20004", it will be as if "PL204" was indexed instead (leading to independant elements "PL", "204" and "PL204" in the search index). This will allow someone searching for "pl204", "pl 204", "pl2004" or "pl 2004" to find the product with the exact "PL2004" sku.

column2: Settings available at the store view scope only.

column2: The ability to select an alternative language stemmer is only available at the store view scope.

column1: Use the default language stemmer as defined in 'elasticsuite_analysis.xml' file for this store language (as defined by the store locale). If set to No, you'll be able to select a different stemmer for languages that have multiple possible stemmers (Dutch, English, Finnish, French, Galician, German, Hungarian, Italian, Norwegian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Swedish).
column2: Use the default language stemmer as defined in 'elasticsuite_analysis.xml' file for this store language (as defined by the store locale). If set to No, you'll be able to select a different stemmer for languages that have multiple possible stemmers (Dutch, English, Finnish, French, Galician, German, Hungarian, Italian, Norwegian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Swedish).

column1: In the list "[default]" indicates the stemmer used by Elasticsuite by default for the language, while "[recommended]" indicates the stemmer is the one or one of those recommended for that language by Elasticsearch in its online documentation. Those can differ, hence this configuration parameter.
column2: In the list "[default]" indicates the stemmer used by Elasticsuite by default for the language, while "[recommended]" indicates the stemmer is the one or one of those recommended for that language by Elasticsearch in its online documentation. Those can differ, hence this configuration parameter.

column1: Please select a stemmer for the store
column2: Please select a stemmer for the store

column1: Time for an index to be considered Ghost (in seconds)
column2: Time for an index to be considered Ghost (in seconds)

column1: Elasticsuite derelict indices resulting from a failed full reindex are considered ghost after this amount of time (in seconds) has elapsed since their creation. You can reduce this amount of time to speed up ghost indices cleanup, but take care to add a safety on top of the maximum reindexing duration of the more complex index of your platform (usually a catalog_product/product search index). Defaults to 172,800 seconds (2 days), minimum value: 3600 (1 hour).
column2: Elasticsuite derelict indices resulting from a failed full reindex are considered ghost after this amount of time (in seconds) has elapsed since their creation. You can reduce this amount of time to speed up ghost indices cleanup, but take care to add a safety on top of the maximum reindexing duration of the more complex index of your platform (usually a catalog_product/product search index). Defaults to 172,800 seconds (2 days), minimum value: 3600 (1 hour).

column1: You have %1 health checks in Failed state. We invite you to head to the Elasticsuite Healthcheck page to get more details and to see how to fix them.
column2: You have %1 health checks in Failed state. We invite you to head to the Elasticsuite Healthcheck page to get more details and to see how to fix them.

column1: Using popular search terms for autocomplete search of products and categories
column2: Using popular search terms for autocomplete search of products and categories

column1:
Historically, both for leveraging user behavioral patterns and performance purposes, Elasticsuite relies on the Popular Search Terms Autocomplete results to complete and extend the search terms submitted by the user before searching for matching products or categories.
For instance, if a user types "comp" in the search box and the suggested popular search terms are "computer", "peach computer", "computer for kids", then categories and products matching either one of those three search terms will be shown and the original "comp" search term is discarded.
On the other hand, if no popular search term is found, then Elasticsuite will try finding products and categories matching only "comp", which might not provide any results unless some attributes have built-in autocompletion capability (by using the "standard_edge_ngram" as their search analyzer).
The settings below provide you with the ability to have more control over that "extension" mechanism: whether to disable it entirely, limit its extend, forcing the original search term to always be requested, etc.
column2:
Historically, both for leveraging user behavioral patterns and performance purposes, Elasticsuite relies on the Popular Search Terms Autocomplete results to complete and extend the search terms submitted by the user before searching for matching products or categories.
For instance, if a user types "comp" in the search box and the suggested popular search terms are "computer", "peach computer", "computer for kids", then categories and products matching either one of those three search terms will be shown and the original "comp" search term is discarded.
On the other hand, if no popular search term is found, then Elasticsuite will try finding products and categories matching only "comp", which might not provide any results unless some attributes have built-in autocompletion capability (by using the "standard_edge_ngram" as their search analyzer).
The settings below provide you with the ability to have more control over that "extension" mechanism: whether to disable it entirely, limit its extend, forcing the original search term to always be requested, etc.

column1: Use suggested search terms to fetch results
column2: Use suggested search terms to fetch results

column1: Default: Yes (legacy behavior). When set to "Yes", products and categories autocomplete will use the search terms suggested in the popular term autocomplete. When set to "No", products and categories autocomplete results will be based solely on the original user raw search term, which might be a partial word being typed (eg "comp" for "computer").
column2: Default: Yes (legacy behavior). When set to "Yes", products and categories autocomplete will use the search terms suggested in the popular term autocomplete. When set to "No", products and categories autocomplete results will be based solely on the original user raw search term, which might be a partial word being typed (eg "comp" for "computer").

column1: Always use the user raw input for suggestions
column2: Always use the user raw input for suggestions

column1: Default: No (legacy behavior). When set to "No", the user raw search term, which might be a partial word being typed, will only be used to fetch suggestions if no matching popular terms were found. When set to "Yes", it will always be used, whether matching popular terms were found or not. Eg if set to "Yes" : when the user is typing "comp" and the popular search term "computer" is suggested, then products or categories matching either "comp" or "computer" will be shown.
column2: Default: No (legacy behavior). When set to "No", the user raw search term, which might be a partial word being typed, will only be used to fetch suggestions if no matching popular terms were found. When set to "Yes", it will always be used, whether matching popular terms were found or not. Eg if set to "Yes" : when the user is typing "comp" and the popular search term "computer" is suggested, then products or categories matching either "comp" or "computer" will be shown.

column1: Limit the amount of suggested search terms used
column2: Limit the amount of suggested search terms used

column1: Default: No (legacy behavior). When set to "No", all the suggested popular search terms will be used for the products and categories autocomplete. When set to "Yes", you will be able to define the maximum number of suggested search terms to use below.
column2: Default: No (legacy behavior). When set to "No", all the suggested popular search terms will be used for the products and categories autocomplete. When set to "Yes", you will be able to define the maximum number of suggested search terms to use below.

column1: Maximum number of popular search terms to use
column2: Maximum number of popular search terms to use

column1: The maximum number of suggested search terms that will be used for fetching results in the products and categories autocomplete boxes. Having a value greater than the "Max Size" defined in the "Popular Term Autocomplete" section above has no effect.
column2: The maximum number of suggested search terms that will be used for fetching results in the products and categories autocomplete boxes. Having a value greater than the "Max Size" defined in the "Popular Term Autocomplete" section above has no effect.

column1: No extension for actual popular search terms
column2: No extension for actual popular search terms

column1: Default: No. When set to "Yes", the extension mechanism will be discarded when the search term entered by the user is amongst the popular terms suggestions. Eg : When the user has finished typing "computer", if the list of suggested search terms is ("computer", "peach computer", "computer for kids"), only "computer" will be taken into account for the products and categories autocomplete.
column2: Default: No. When set to "Yes", the extension mechanism will be discarded when the search term entered by the user is amongst the popular terms suggestions. Eg : When the user has finished typing "computer", if the list of suggested search terms is ("computer", "peach computer", "computer for kids"), only "computer" will be taken into account for the products and categories autocomplete.
